## Exponential function - The exponential function has the form $\displaystyle y= f(x) =a^x$: - $a$ is a constant known as the base, $a \gt 0$ and $a \ne 0$. - $x$ is the exponent. - The natural exponential function $y = e^x$ is a specific type of exponential functions where the base is the constant $e$, known as Euler’s number ($e \approx 2.718281828459045…$). - A graphical presentation of an exponential function with bases less or greater than $1$ is depicted in Figure 1. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Plot of exponential functions with bases less or greater than 1](007_logs_and_exp_files/figure-html/fig-1-1.png){#fig-1 width=672} ::: ::: ## Logarithmic function - The logarithmic function has the form $y = f(x) = \log_ax$: - $a$ is a constant known as the base of logarithm, $a \gt 0$ and $a \ne 1$. - $x \gt 0$ (i.e., the function is defined only if $x$ is positive). - It is read as $\log$ to the base $a$ of $x$. - If the base $a=10$, then it is known as the common logarithm ($\log$), but if $a = e$, then it is known as the natural logarithm ($\ln$). - R function for the common logarithm is `log10()` and for the natural logarithm is `log()`. - A graphical presentation of the logarithmic function $y =log_{10}\ x$ is depicted in Figure 2. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](007_logs_and_exp_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Relation between exponential and logarithmic functions - Each function is the inverse of the other (i.e., each function undoes the other): - $a^{\log_ax} = x$, for $x>0$ - $\log_a a^x = x$ - If $a^y = x$, then $y = \log_a x$. - Similarly, if $\log_a x = y$, then $x = a^y$. ## Basic laws of exponents 1. $a^m a^n = a^{m+n}$ 2. $\displaystyle \frac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}$ 3. $(a^m)^n = a^{mn}$ 4. $(ab)^n = a^nb^n$ 5. $\displaystyle (\frac{a}{b})^n = \frac{a^n}{b^n}$ 6. $a^0 = 1$ 7. $\displaystyle a^{-n} = \frac{1}{a^n}$ 8. $\displaystyle a^{\frac{1}{n}} =\sqrt[n]{a}$, this is referred to as the $n^{th}$ root of $a$ 9. $\displaystyle a^{\frac{m}{n}} = \sqrt[n]{a^m}$ ::: panel-tabset ## Example M.7.1 {{< iconify ic:round-menu-book size=21px >}} Calculate $\displaystyle \frac{2^7}{2^5} + 4^0$ $$ \displaystyle \frac{2^7}{2^5} + 4^0 = $$ $$ \displaystyle 2^{(7-5)} + 4^0\ {\color{#0466c8}(\text {apply rule 2}\rightarrow)} = $$ $$ \displaystyle 2^2 + 1\ {\color{#0466c8}(\text {apply rule 6}\rightarrow)} = $$ $$ \displaystyle 4 + 1 = 5 $$ ::: ## Basic laws of logarithms 1. $\log_a x^b = b\log_a x$ 2. $\log_a (xy) = \log_a x + \log_a y$ 3. $\log_a \frac{x}{y} = \log_a x - \log_a y$ 4. $\log_a x = \displaystyle \frac{\log_b x}{\log_b a}$ 5. $\log_a x = \displaystyle \frac{1}{\log_x a}$ 6. $\log_a 1 = 0$ 7. $\log_a a = 1$ ::: panel-tabset ## Example M.7.2 {{< iconify ic:round-menu-book size=21px >}} Write $(4 \log_{10} x + 3 \log_{10} 5y)$ as a single logarithm. $$ 4 \log_{10} x + 3 \log_{10} 5y = $$ $$ \log_{10} x^4 + \log_{10} (5y)^3 {\color{#0466c8}(\text {apply rule 1}\rightarrow)} = $$ $$ \log_{10} x^4 \cdot (5y)^3 {\color{#0466c8}(\text {apply rule 2}\rightarrow)} = $$ $$ \log_{10} 125 x^4 y^3 $$ ::: {style="color: #0466c8;"} ::: callout-note To apply the above manipulations, the base of the logarithm should be the same for all terms. ::: ::: ## [Exercise M.7.1 {{< iconify fluent:chat-bubbles-question-20-filled size=21px >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} Solve the equation $125^{x-2} = 5^{2-x}$ for $x$
$$ 125^{x-2} = 5^{2-x} \Rightarrow $$ $$ (5^3)^{x-2} = 5^{2-x} \Rightarrow $$ $$ 5^{3 (x-2)} = 5^{2-x} \Rightarrow $$ $$ 5^{3x-6} = 5^{2-x} \Rightarrow $$ $$ 3x-6 = 2-x \Rightarrow $$ $$ 3x+x = 2+6 \Rightarrow $$ $$ 4x = 8 \Rightarrow $$ $$ x = 2 $$
